posts.title: The Human Comedy
posts.excerpt: Plot: Homer Macauley remains in a small town looking after his widowed mother and younger brother. Homer’s older brother is fighting the war in Europe. Written by Anonymous

posts._title: Orson Welles – Don Quijote de Orson Welles (1992)
posts.title: Don Quijote de Orson Welles
posts.excerpt: “Perhaps the most fascinating component of the films directed by Orson Welles was the masterpiece he never lived to complete. Beginning in 1957 and continuing on-and-off for the next 15 years, Welles self-financed and directed an audacious film version of Cervantes’ “Don Quixote” which brought the legendary knight and his rotund aide Sancho Panza out …

posts._title: Mrinal Sen – Ek Din Pratidin aka And Quiet Rolls the Day (1979)
posts.title: Ek Din Pratidin
posts.excerpt: Plot synopsis:The bread-winning daughter in a middle-class family fails to return from work one evening. The night begins with worries at home, followed by midnight searches and finally a deepening crisis arising out of economic and moral constraints prevalent in the society. Yet the film speaks of hope, of strength hidden behind despair.

posts.title: Madame X
posts.excerpt: The lower-class wife (Lana Turner) of a wealthy socialite (John Forsythe) is caught in a compromising situation with a male companion (Ricardo Montalban), and forced by her brutal mother-in-law (Constance Bennett) to “die” and live under an assumed name in Europe. Out of guilt and loyalty, she forgoes a renewed chance at romance with a …

posts._title: Mabel Cheung – Ba liang jin AKA Eight Taels of Gold (1989)
posts.title: Ba liang jin
posts.excerpt: Quote:Mabel Cheung may be one of the lesser known names of the early 80s Hong Kong New-Wave – directors such as Tsui Hark and Ann Hui gaining a greater attention worldwide – yet she has an indelible auteur’s stamp that ensure her greater works will stand the test of time. The subtle strokes which she …

posts.title: Loot
posts.excerpt: Synopsis:This adaptation of Joe Orton’s play focuses on a motley bunch of characters crammed inside a small hotel owned by Mr. McLeavy (Milo O’Shea). While the body of McLeavy’s wife lies freshly dead in a nearby room, her nurse, Fay (Lee Remick), plots to become the next Mrs. McLeavy. Meanwhile, McLeavy’s son and his friend …

posts.title: London Kills Me
posts.excerpt: The ambitious leader of an undisciplined gang is trying to break into the big time. Meanwhile, his best friend is trying to leave the gang. The key to his new life is a new pair of shoes, but not just any pair of shoes — a pair of red cowboy boots.

posts._title: Werner Herzog – Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)
posts.title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World
posts.excerpt: Quote:“I think anyone who claims they know what’s going to happen to the internet is not worth listening to.” This summation of the way we understand and can predict the interconnectivity of the future seems an apposite way to begin a discussion of Werner Herzog’s expansive, nebulous investigation in Lo and Behold, Reveries of the …

posts._title: Terence Fisher – The Revenge of Frankenstein (1958) (HD)
posts.title: The Revenge of Frankenstein (1958)
posts.excerpt: Plot: Baron Frankenstein escapes from the guillotine and goes to Germany. There, he names himself Dr. Stein and plans to restart his experiments by using parts of dead bodies.

posts._title: René Clair – Les fêtes galantes AKA The Lace Wars (1965)
posts.title: Les fêtes galantes
posts.excerpt: Having lost a battle against the Prince of Beaulieu, Marechal d’Allenberg returns to his castle with his few remaining followers. As famine takes its toll, one of d’Allenberg’s men, Joli Coeur, sets off to look for food. The latter not only finds some pork, but he also saves the honour of a beautiful girl who …
